original_theorem:
Let $f$ be a real-valued function defined on a subset of $\R^n,$
 and let the
vector-valued function $\mathbf{G}=(g_1,g_2, \dots,g_n)$ be defined on a
domain $D_\mathbf{G}$ in $\R^m.$ Let the set
$$
T=\set{\mathbf{U}}{\mathbf{U}\in D_{\mathbf{G}}\mbox{\quad and \quad}
\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})\in D_f}
$$
$($Figure~\ref{figure:5.2.3}$)$,
 be
nonempty$,$ and define the real-valued composite function
$$
h=f\circ\mathbf{G}
$$
on $T$ by
$$
h(\mathbf{U})=f(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U})),\quad \mathbf{U}\in T.
$$
Now suppose that  $\mathbf{U}_0$ is in $T$ and is a limit point of $T,$
$\mathbf{G}$ is continuous at $\mathbf{U}_0,$ and $f$ is continuous at
$\mathbf{X}_0=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{U}_0).$ Then $h$ is continuous at
$\mathbf{U}_0.$

    {f : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin n) â†’ â„}
    {D_f : Set (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin n))}
    -- Let G be a function from a domain D_G in â„áµ to â„â¿.
    {G : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin m) â†’ EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin n)}
    {D_G : Set (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin m))}
    -- Let Uâ‚€ be a point in â„áµ.
    {Uâ‚€ : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin m)}
    -- Define the domain of the composite function h = f âˆ˜ G.
    (T := D_G âˆ© G â»Â¹' D_f)
    -- Suppose that Uâ‚€ is in T.
    (h_Uâ‚€_in_T : Uâ‚€ âˆˆ T)
    -- Suppose G is continuous at Uâ‚€ within its domain D_G.
    (h_G_continuous : ContinuousWithinAt G D_G Uâ‚€)
    -- And suppose f is continuous at G(Uâ‚€) within its domain D_f.
    (h_f_continuous : ContinuousWithinAt f D_f (G Uâ‚€)) :
  -- Then the composite function h is continuous at Uâ‚€ within its domain T.
  ContinuousWithinAt (f âˆ˜ G) T Uâ‚€ := by
